summary.narrative: Novati Constructions, a Sydney builder operating since 1971, entered voluntary administration on 8 February 2026 (public announcement 13 Feb). The family-run company had a portfolio spanning residential, commercial, industrial, aged care and education projects. At collapse, active projects included the Loftex warehouse ($30M), Embassy Residences, Georges Manor Aged Care, and the Manly Civic Club fitout. Directors are proposing a Deed of Company Arrangement. MBA NSW Award winner 2017.

projects.notes: 25,000sqm warehouse + 1,000sqm office. ESD features. Repeat Loftex client.
Major industrial warehouse project.
Luxury apartment complex. One of Novati's most recent successes.

projects.projectName: Sargood on Collaroy — Spinal Care & Rehabilitation
projects.notes: MBA NSW Excellence Award 2017 ($10-15M category). Disability accommodation.

sourceArticles.title: Veteran Sydney builder Novati Constructions collapses into voluntary administration
sourceArticles.summary: Novati Constructions Pty Ltd, founded 1971 by Peter Novati, entered voluntary administration. Administrators Graeme Beattie and Aaron Lucan of Worrells appointed 8 Feb 2026. First creditors' meeting scheduled 18 Feb 2026. Directors Luisa and Marco Novati. Notable projects: Dicker Data warehouse (Kurnell), luxury apartments South Cronulla, Manly Civic Club fit-out, Sargood on Collaroy (MBA NSW award 2017). 1,567 construction companies entered administration in FY2025. Directors expressed desire to propose a Deed of Company Arrangement.

summary.narrative: SMLXL Projects, a niche NSW design-and-construction firm ranked 11th on the AFR Fast Starters 2018 list, was placed into liquidation on 4 July 2023. At its peak the company was managing 130 projects across Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth, with $20M in revenues. The collapse left several major projects in limbo including the Mona Vale Golf Club clubhouse (gutted mid-renovation), Rafi Restaurant North Sydney, Glorietta's Restaurant North Sydney, and the Manly Wharf Hotel. Directors: Dean Ossip (founder) and Lisa Mort (CEO from March 2021). Joint liquidators Trent Devine and Peter Moore appointed.

summary.narrative: Australex Group Pty Ltd, described as an 'award-winning, boutique residential and commercial builder' offering in-house design, engineering, formwork and joinery services, entered Creditors' Voluntary Liquidation on 18 August 2023. Projects included 10 apartments in Neutral Bay (completed 2022) and 60 apartments in Wiley Park (under construction at time of collapse). Related entity Australex Construction Pty Ltd (ACN 161924965) was proposed for deregistration in June 2023. summary.narrative: ProBuild was one of Australia's largest builders with $5B in active projects when it collapsed in February 2022. WBHO South Africa withdrew support on 22 February after years of losses. The administrator found the company had been insolvent since at least 1 February — just 22 days of confirmed insolvent trading. But the scale of impact was enormous: 2,300 creditors, workers owed $14M, and projects from Sydney's tallest residential tower to Perth's Ritz Carlton left in limbo. Roberts Co later purchased ProBuild's VIC operations for just $1.

summary.narrative: Element Five (Aust) Pty Ltd, a boutique multi-residential builder in Melbourne and sister company of VCON, entered voluntary administration on 13 March 2025 owing $3.7M to creditors. The collapse was triggered by a Brighton project dispute that damaged the VCON Group's reputation and cash flow. The Brunswick Yard project ($50M, 122 apartments) suffered $1M+ in sabotage damage from unpaid subcontractors. Director Anthony Morton failed to return mandatory ROCAP report. Joint liquidators Andrew Hewitt & Matt Byrnes (Grant Thornton) appointed June 25, 2025.

summary.narrative: Roberts Co's Victorian arm collapsed in March 2025 with 8 active projects worth $2.2B. The Craigieburn Amazon warehouse alone — Australia's largest, the size of 11 MCGs — lost $56.1M. Five of the 8 projects were inherited from ProBuild's 2022 collapse (purchased for $1). McGrathNicol found potential insolvent trading since December 2024 (103 days). Owner Andrew Roberts (Multiplex heir) stopped funding losses from his personal fortune. NSW arm later sold to UAE's Arada.

summary.narrative: Stokes Wheeler, a Gold Coast builder operating for nearly 100 years, collapsed into administration on 3 February 2025, then liquidation on 14 April 2025. Staff owed $1.66M, unsecured creditors $13.5M, Westpac secured debt $2.97M — total debts ~$20M. All 6 project trust accounts had zero funds. 4 major projects worth $73M were abandoned: Elevaire (40 apartments, Palm Beach), Bounce Hostel (Surfers Paradise), a medical centre (Pimpama), and an aged care facility (Sunnybank). Administrators found the company had traded while insolvent and faced financial pressure for 5 years.

summary.narrative: Pindan Group, a major WA property and construction company based in Belmont, collapsed into administration on 18 May 2021 with 68 active projects, 280 direct employees, and $70-80M owed to 1,400 creditors (500 subcontractors, 40 suppliers). Major projects included the Kings Square / Walyalup Civic Centre in Fremantle (Kerry Hill Architects), extensive social housing programs across WA, and east coast expansion into the Sunshine Coast. The collapse was blamed on COVID-19 pandemic delays and prompted urgent calls for subcontractor protection reforms in WA.

summary.narrative: North-West Coast Tasmania franchisee of Hotondo Homes national brand. Entered liquidation 22 January 2026. $1.7M in debts to contractors, subcontractors and employees (unpaid super). Up to 12 families affected — either holding large deposits or with incomplete homes. Director Luke Jones failed to renew building licence December 2025 after months of financial pressure including failing to pay contractors on time. Hotondo national office had been working with the franchisee since February 2025.

sourceArticles.title: Tasmanian builder collapses with $1.7M debts, unfinished homes
sourceArticles.summary: LJones Construction (trading as Hotondo Homes North West Tas) entered liquidation 22 Jan 2026. $1.7M debts to contractors/subcontractors/employees. Up to 12 families with deposits or incomplete homes. Liquidator Shelley-Maree Brooks appointed. Director Luke Jones didn't renew building licence Dec 2025 after months of financial pressure. Hotondo national office had been assisting since Feb 2025. CBOS contacting affected consumers re: government assistance. HIA Tasmania cited 'elevated input costs' and 'regulatory churn' as industry pressures.
